name: 2,4-dichlorobenzyl alcohol
Reason: 2,4-dichlorobenzyl alcohol has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The introduction of the chlorine atom increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the formation of hydrogen bonds with the alcohol group, estimated at around +10°C. The phenyl group also contributes to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20°C. The dichloro group introduces additional rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5°C. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to its small size and limited ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around -5°C.
